1790s–1828; Formed to oppose Federalists; favored state over national government

1825–1834; Split from Democratic-Republicans to oppose Andrew Jackson and work for strong central government

Democratic:

1825–Present; Formed from Democratic-Republicans; supported Andrew Jackson and "common people"; today supports a more active role of government

Whig:

1834–1854; Formed from National Republicans and other parties; favored internal improvements

Republican:

1854–Present; Formed from Whigs and other groups; opposed spread of slavery to new territories and favored internal improvements; today supports a limited role of government

activity.text:
Third Parties

Minor or third parties rarely win major elections in the United States. Why is this the case?

For one thing, the United States' electoral system—which is made up of single-member districts—makes it difficult for third parties to compete. Also, American politics has traditionally been characterized by compromise and negotiation between the two major parties, which allows their candidates to appeal to more voters.

Some third parties form over a single issue, such as slavery. Some have formed over a political figure, such as Theodore Roosevelt's Bull Moose Progressive Party. Others form over an ideology, like the Communist Party USA or, more recently, the Tea Party—a conservative party that promotes less government, fiscal responsibility, and states' rights. Although third parties might not have a strong chance of winning, they often influence politics by promoting new ideas.

hotspots.hotspot:
Electoral system

a legal voting system for making democratic choices

Single-member districts

a voting district in which one representative is elected to serve in a body such as a legislature

Ideology

a highly organized framework of beliefs concerning the nature and role of government in society

National Convention

The national party's meeting, held in the summer of a presidential election year, in which each state sends delegates to nominate the party's candidates for president and vice president

Caucus

A meeting of the members of a political party, especially to select delegates to a convention

Nominating Convention

The meeting of party leaders to nominate party candidates at any level

Primary Election

Election held before the general election in which party members or voters select candidates for the general election

Direct Primary

Election held before the general election in which voters directly choose the candidates for the general election; Depending on a state's election rules, the candidate who wins the primary gets all of the state's convention delegates (called "winner-take-all"), or each candidate gets delegates based on the proportion of how many popular votes he or she receives in the primary.

Platform

An official statement of a political party's views and policies on political issues

content.header: How Media Impact Government and Politics
content.text:
The mass media includes print media and broadcast media. The Internet has emerged as a powerful new interactive medium. The relationship between the media and U.S. government officials is complex. They need to work together, but their jobs often place them in adversarial positions.

The president and television have a mutually beneficial relationship. The president is a great source of news, and television offers presidents the best way to "sell" their ideas and policies to the public. White House staff media advisers control the daily flow of information through news releases and briefings, press conferences, background stories, leaks, and media events.

Congress gets less media coverage than the president because most legislative work takes place in committees and subcommittees over long periods of time. When Congress is in the news, reporters tend to focus on controversial issues such as confirmation hearings, oversight activities, or the personal lives of members. C-SPAN broadcasts floor proceedings of the House and Senate.

During election season, television greatly influences who runs for office, how candidates are nominated, and campaign advertising. Television lets candidates appeal directly to the people. TV ads also allow candidates to make their opponents look unappealing.
